messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:35): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Opera throws WRONG_ARGUMENT_ERR or some such
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:35): It's a clearer error name than TypeError.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:35): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: oh okay :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:36): I think nobody has taken a critical look yet at that part of Web IDL
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:36): apart from maybe Microsoft but they don't give feedback until it is shipped typically
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:40): I like TypeError
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:40): I think aligining with javascript native APIs is a win

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:41): Also, I notice that Alex doesn't really talk about the user or vendor point of view of prefixes, only the author point of view. It is pretty easy to say that prefixes are awesome when you work on webkit and are sure that everyone will include a -webkit- prefix always
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:47): Hixie: re: time element text update, minor tweak:
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:48): s/The datetime attribute must be present. Its value must be/The datetime attribute, if present, must be
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:48): since we explicitly allow <time>2011</time> etc. (even prefer)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:48): to reduce DRY violations
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:49): also, example still to be fixed:

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:51): regarding time zone offsets, experience has shown that *dropping* the ":" between the hours/minutes on timezone offsets helps better distinguish them from appearing like times
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:52): e.g. 07:00-0800 is more obviously 7am in PST than
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:52): 07:00-08:00 which looks like an interval of 7am to 8am.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:52): whoever started with sub-hour timezone offsets needs to be shot into the sun
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:52): this is a human authorability/readability/verfiability concern
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:53): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 I believe there is even a country that has a half-hour DST change.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:53): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: -0800 is also just a common notation that people are familiar with
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:53): dbaron would know
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:53): i've heard of at least one place with a 15-minute offset :|
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:54): I'm fine with parsing with the colon as error recovery, however we should make timezone offsets valid only *without* the ":" between HH MM.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): yeah, around India there's some fun stuff
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:55): India in fact has the half an hour
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:56): Bangladesh might be the one with three quarters?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:56): Hixie, regarding year-less date parsing:
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:56): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#parse-a-yearless-date-string
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:56): oh, Nepal is
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:56): in Kathmandu it's 21:35 now
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:56): please explicitly allow the leading double-hyphen
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:56): making it optional is fine
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (16:57): as that's the ISO8601 syntax for yearless dates
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:57): Chatham Islands in New Zealand have a similar weird offset
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:57): there it's 05:35
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:58): if we have offsets at all it doesn't really matter how arbitrary they are
